clean_story:
"Self-awareness. The brain observing itself. "

The phrase describes how your brain can think about its own thoughts—like a mirror reflecting another mirror.

Most brains react to the world automatically, like a thermostat adjusting temperature.

But humans can pause and ask: "Why did I think that?"

This happens in the prefrontal cortex, the brain’s "planning center. "

When you daydream about your daydream, or catch yourself overthinking, that’s your brain watching itself work.

Scans show this creates a loop: the anterior cingulate cortex flags mistakes, while the default mode network replays past events.

It’s like a director reviewing footage while filming.

Too much self-focus can trap you—like a computer stuck debugging itself.

But in balance, it lets you learn, adapt, and even change your mind.

Three related subjects are mindfulness meditation techniques, AI self-monitoring systems, and dissociation in psychology.
